title: I am writing a novel that I've been planning for two years now, but I am only fifteen, should I wait until I am older, or finish writing to publish? - Quora

response.answer_text: I'd say you should focus on finishing your draft.  Just keep in mind that unless you're unusually talented it's probably not going to be your last one.The first book I published I actually conceived of when I was about 10 years old.  I ended up rewriting it when I was 14.  When I was 20, I adapted it into a game, and the book was released (unfortunately largely unchanged from the draft I wrote when I was 14) to promote the project during development.The game, sadly, didn't end up seeing release, but the book sold, and the sequel (written properly) sold even better and is something I'm actual Continue Reading

You should definitely finish your novel before you publish it. In addition, find a an editor who will be brutally honest with you about your writing style, grammar, characters, etc.  Edit, revise, edit, revise. You want this thing to be perfect. All the hot authors from King to Scalzi will tell you to write every day, and write a lot. Most authors end up writing 3-6 books before they get good enough to publish one.  When you/your editor think your book is ready, go for it! First of all, congratulations on your venture writing a novel, it is an exciting journey. Answering your question, no, you should not stop writing and wait until you are older.It is never too early or too late to write. Also, at 15, you are in an age of discovery and self development, the next few years will shape your personality and your views of the world and, because you are in this transitional period in your life, if you stopped writing your novel now and get back to it years later, you would realise you are not "the same person" as you were at 15 and that will be reflected in your writin Continue Reading

"Eragon is the first novel in the Inheritance Cycle by Christopher Paolini, who began writing at the age of 15. After writing the first draft for a year, Paolini spent a second year rewriting and fleshing out the story and characters. Paolini's parents saw the final manuscript and decided to self-publish Eragon. Paolini spent a year traveling around the United States promoting the novel. By chance, the book was discovered by Carl Hiaasen, who got it re-published by Alfred A. Knopf. The re-published version was released on August 26, 2003." -- Wikipedia If he can do it, you can do it.

Stop "planning", start "writing".   Go through about ten drafts and then show it to people.   See what they think.   They'll tell you.   Incorporate their suggestions (if they are good ones) into your work.   When you think it is ready, or at least not so embarrassingly bad that you're ashamed of it, share it with literary agents and editors.

Ditto! Keep writing and have a trusted adult involved when you start to submit to publishers or get an agent.  In addition to Christopher Paolini, Nancy Yi Fan had her first book, SWORDBIRD, accepted when she was 13! The book was a NYT bestseller and there are others in the series. Enjoy the process and take your time to make the book the best it can possibly be. Denise

It takes a lot of creativity and hard work to give birth to the characters, the emotions and the plots which connects them and the story that is born out of a smart amalgamation of such beautiful elements.So, if you're able to come up with a story which pleases you as a reader, trust me the age is nothing but a silly number which is plane insignificant.

Short answer : Just Do It!! Why do you want to wait? You are going to write many many more novels before you are 30! Just three pieces of advice :   Find a good publisher who will help you edit before publication.2. Have a forward written by a successful writer; and  3. A clever title and book cover.

My brave friend,Do it Now Now Now! Write everyday! You will write, you will edit and you will prevail! If for some reason your work is never published? You will ALWAYS have it. It's a piece of you. Good luck!
Join Wattpad. Write everyday. Better to start writing stories before attempting novels.  Short stories are actually harder to write.
maybe you could share your thoughts to your parents,friends before you write it on paper,and let them give you some advice.
